alt_statements.statement: I think immigration policy should be fair and kind, giving people who work hard, follow the rules, and want to contribute a real chance to become citizens. Families shouldn’t be torn apart, especially when there are kids involved, and people should be treated with respect no matter where they come from. Since I was born here but my family is Filipino, I feel like America should stay open to different cultures while still keeping everyone safe and making sure the laws are followed.

As a longtime Delaware resident and liberal Democrat, I think our immigration policy should balance compassion with clear, well-enforced rules. We ought to have a fair, straightforward path to citizenship for people who work hard, follow the law, and contribute to their communities, including paying taxes and learning English. As a Christian, I believe we have a moral duty to treat immigrants with dignity and avoid demonizing them, while still maintaining secure borders and a system that the public can trust.

I think immigration rules should be fair and kind, because my church teaches that we should welcome and help people, especially families and kids. People who follow the laws, work hard, and want to be good citizens should have a clear and honest way to become Americans, just like my family has always lived here.

I believe immigration policy should balance compassion with fairness and security, welcoming those who want to work hard, follow the law, and contribute to our communities. As a parent and someone who values stability, I think the path to citizenship should be clear, orderly, and not so burdensome that it pushes people into the shadows—but it also needs real vetting and enforcement so people trust the system.

Immigration policy should balance compassion with clear, enforceable rules, creating an efficient, transparent path to citizenship for people who work hard, follow the law, and contribute to our communities and economy. As someone who grew up in New Mexico and works in a field built on fairness, I believe we need stronger due process protections, humane treatment at the border, and a streamlined system that prioritizes family unity, labor needs, and long-term residents who are already part of the social fabric.

As someone who works in national security and is trying to raise a young family, I believe immigration policy has to start with strong borders, strict enforcement of existing laws, and thorough vetting to protect Americans. At the same time, we should have a clear, orderly, and fair legal path to citizenship for those who follow the rules, contribute to our economy, and embrace our language, laws, and values. That path shouldn’t reward illegal entry or jump anyone ahead of those who have waited in line, but it also shouldn’t trap hardworking families in permanent limbo. As a Catholic, I think we’re called to balance compassion with responsibility: treating people with dignity while prioritizing the safety, stability, and cohesion of our country.

As a conservative and a lifelong American, I believe our immigration policy should start with secure borders, the consistent enforcement of existing laws, and a clear priority on the safety and economic stability of citizens. At the same time, we should maintain a fair, orderly, and transparent legal path to citizenship that rewards those who respect our laws, contribute to our communities, and embrace our values and institutions.

Immigration policy should be guided by fairness, human dignity, and a clear, realistic path to citizenship for people who are already contributing to their communities and the economy, like many of us working here on visas. As someone who immigrated from Nicaragua and believes in social justice, I think the system should prioritize family unity, protect vulnerable people, and reduce unnecessary bureaucracy that keeps talented, hardworking individuals in limbo for years. At the same time, it should maintain reasonable security checks and transparent rules so that the process feels orderly and legitimate for everyone.

I think immigration rules should be fair and kind, because my church teaches that everyone is a child of God and deserves to be treated with respect. We should have strong safety checks so people follow the laws, but we should also make it possible for good, hardworking families to become citizens and stay together. Kids who grow up here, go to school here, and feel American should have a clear and simple way to become citizens too.

As a teacher and a Catholic, I believe our immigration policy and path to citizenship should balance the rule of law with basic human dignity and compassion. We ought to create a clear, efficient, and fair process that prioritizes family unity, offers an attainable path to citizenship for long-term, law-abiding residents (including Dreamers), and recognizes the economic and cultural contributions immigrants make to our communities. At the same time, we should invest in smart, humane border management and address the climate and conflict-driven causes of migration, so people aren’t forced to leave their homes in the first place.

Immigration policy and the path to citizenship should be fair, humane, and efficient, recognizing that our country is stronger when we welcome people who contribute to our communities and respect democratic values. As someone who grew up with a lot of opportunity and security, I think it’s only right that we make it possible for undocumented immigrants—especially kids and long-term residents—to earn citizenship through education, work, and a clean record, rather than living in constant fear. We should also prioritize family unity, protect refugees and asylum seekers, and ensure that the process is transparent and not biased by race, religion, or wealth.

As a police officer and a proud American, I believe immigration policy must start with secure borders, strict enforcement of existing laws, and zero tolerance for criminal activity from anyone—citizen or non-citizen. I support a clear, orderly, and merit-based path to citizenship for those who come here legally, respect our laws, learn English, and commit to contributing to our communities and embracing American values.

As a Catholic and a Democrat, I believe our immigration policy should balance compassion and the rule of law, recognizing the dignity of people who come here seeking safety and opportunity while maintaining secure, orderly borders. We should have a clear, realistic path to citizenship for long-term, law-abiding residents—especially Dreamers and essential workers—grounded in background checks, fair taxation, and civic integration like learning English and understanding our institutions.

As someone who came to this country from Mexico and worked hard in a small business, I believe immigration policy should be firm but fair, respecting the laws while also recognizing the dignity of those who seek a better life. The path to citizenship should require learning English, paying taxes, following the law, and contributing to the community, but it should also offer mercy and a clear process for families who have been here many years. A nation has the right to protect its borders, yet as Catholics we must remember our duty to treat migrants with compassion and justice.

I believe immigration policy should prioritize border security, the rule of law, and the economic needs of American workers, especially those of us in lower-wage jobs who already struggle to get by. I support legal immigration with strict background checks and a clear, orderly process, but I don’t think people who enter the country illegally should be rewarded with an easy path to citizenship over those who follow the rules.

As someone who came here from Korea and works hard every day in a restaurant kitchen, I believe immigration policy should reward those who follow the rules, pay taxes, and contribute to their communities. There should be a clear, step-by-step path to legal status and eventually citizenship, but it must include strict background checks, proof of steady work, and respect for American laws and values. Legal immigration should be prioritized, and the government needs to secure the borders so that people who are waiting and doing things the right way aren’t punished.

As someone who believes in the rule of law and national security, I think immigration policy should prioritize secure borders, thorough vetting, and enforcement of existing laws, while still recognizing America as a place of opportunity for those who play by the rules. A fair path to citizenship should reward legal immigration, require English proficiency and steady employment, and emphasize learning our history and values so new citizens are truly committed to this country.

As a Christian and a conservative, I believe immigration policy should be guided by both compassion and order: we must uphold the rule of law and protect our nation’s security while also treating every person with dignity as someone made in God’s image. I support a fair but firm system that secures the border, enforces existing laws, and provides a clear, structured path to citizenship for those who come legally, work hard, respect our values, and contribute to our communities.

I think immigration policy ought to put American citizens first, protect our borders, and make sure people follow the law just like I had to follow the rules in my time. I’m not against folks coming here for a better life, but the path to citizenship should be earned through hard work, learning our language and history, paying taxes, and showing real loyalty to this country.

I think immigration policy should be fair and humane, because my family’s Catholic faith teaches that everyone has dignity, no matter where they’re from. There should be background checks and rules to keep people safe, but there also needs to be a clear, realistic path to citizenship for people who work hard, follow the law, and want to be part of our communities.

I think our immigration policy should balance strong border security and enforcement with a fair, realistic path to citizenship for people who follow the rules, work hard, and contribute to our communities. As someone who works in a factory and comes from Polish roots myself, I respect legal processes and want everyone held to the same standards, but I also believe in treating people with dignity and giving those already here, paying taxes, and staying out of trouble a chance to come out of the shadows. A good system would prioritize background checks, English learning, and steady employment, while avoiding extremes on either side and keeping families together whenever possible.

I think our immigration policy should be firm, fair, and focused on rewarding people who follow the rules and want to work hard, like a lot of folks I meet on the road. We ought to secure the border and enforce existing laws, but we should also have a clear, straightforward path to citizenship for law-abiding immigrants who contribute to the economy, learn English, and respect our values and freedoms.

As someone who immigrated from Mexico and became a U.S. citizen, I believe immigration policy should be fair, humane, and realistic about the needs of families and our economy. There should be a clear, affordable, and timely path to citizenship for people who work hard, follow the laws, and contribute to their communities, especially those raising children here. Our policies should keep families together, protect children, and respect human dignity, while also ensuring secure and well-managed borders.

As a Black man from North Carolina whose family history is rooted in struggles for basic rights, I think immigration policy should be grounded in fairness, human dignity, and equal opportunity. We should have a clear, humane path to citizenship that doesn’t tear families apart, protects workers from exploitation, and recognizes how much immigrants contribute to education, our economy, and our culture.

I think immigration policy should put Americans’ security, jobs, and resources first, with strict border control and strong enforcement of the laws we already have. People who want to come here and eventually become citizens ought to do it legally, pass thorough background checks, work, pay taxes, and learn English and our civic values. I’m not against immigration, but the numbers and the process have to be controlled and orderly, so we know who is here and that they’re contributing.

I believe immigration policy should prioritize security, the rule of law, and the needs of American workers, especially those of us in low-wage jobs who already struggle to get by. I’m not against legal immigration, but I think the process should be strict, clearly enforced, and focused on people who are willing to work hard, respect our culture and laws, and contribute positively. A path to citizenship should be earned through things like learning English, paying taxes, and following the law, not just given automatically.

As the grandson of Swedish immigrants and a lifelong Minnesotan, I think our immigration policy should balance strong, smart security with a fair, humane path to citizenship. We should invest in modern, evidence-based border and identity technologies, while offering an efficient, transparent process for law‑abiding immigrants, Dreamers, and long-term residents to become full participants in our democracy. For me, the guiding principles are dignity, due process, and practicality: protect the integrity of our systems, but never lose sight of the people and families whose lives are shaped by them.

Immigration policy should prioritize the security and well-being of American citizens while respecting the rule of law. We should welcome immigrants who come here legally, are willing to work hard, follow our laws, and embrace our values, but we must strongly enforce our borders and immigration regulations. The path to citizenship ought to be orderly, merit-based, and fair, rewarding those who contribute positively to our society and economy.

I believe our immigration policy should put the safety, stability, and values of American citizens first, while still treating everyone with basic dignity and fairness. We should have strong, consistently enforced borders, a clear legal process, and a path to citizenship that requires learning English, respecting our laws, and contributing through honest work and taxes.

I think people who want to come live here should follow the rules, be peaceful, and try to help make our country better, just like my teachers say we should do in our class and community. It’s important that families can stay together and that kids are safe, no matter where they were born. If someone works hard, is kind, and respects our laws and the land, there should be a fair way for them to become a citizen over time.

As a lifelong Floridian, a Catholic, and someone who believes deeply in the strength of community, I think our immigration policy should balance compassion with clear, enforceable rules. We need a humane, efficient path to citizenship that welcomes hardworking families, keeps them safe from exploitation, and recognizes the contributions they make to our schools, neighborhoods, and economy. At the same time, we should maintain secure, orderly borders and expect newcomers to follow our laws, learn English, and participate fully in civic life. This approach reflects both my faith’s call to care for the stranger and my belief in a fair, well-functioning system that strengthens our shared future.

As a Catholic and a conservative, I believe our immigration policy should uphold both the rule of law and the dignity of every human person. We need strong, secure borders and a clear, orderly system so people come here the right way, respect our laws, and work toward learning our language and embracing American values. I support a tough but fair path to citizenship that includes background checks, paying taxes, and demonstrating commitment to this country, while also keeping families together when possible.

I think immigration policy should be fair, orderly, and humane, with clear rules that people can realistically follow to work, live, and eventually become citizens if they contribute and follow the law. As someone who serves a lot of different people every day and grew up valuing hard work and independence, I believe we should welcome immigrants who want to build a life here while also having secure borders and reasonable limits so the system stays manageable and safe.

As an Indian researcher on a temporary visa working at a state university, I think immigration policy and the path to citizenship should be grounded in fairness, human dignity, and a clear recognition of immigrants’ economic and intellectual contributions. We should have transparent, predictable pathways that prioritize family unity, humanitarian protection, and the needs of key sectors like education and science—rather than arbitrary caps or political cycles. A just system would make long-term residents who pay taxes, follow the law, and contribute to their communities eligible for an attainable, timely route to citizenship. Ultimately, a progressive democracy should treat immigrants not as disposable labor, but as future citizens and full participants in civic life.

As a Mexican American and a mom, I believe our immigration policy should reflect both the rule of law and the compassion and opportunity my own family has benefited from. We should create a fair, efficient path to citizenship that prioritizes keeping families together, offers a clear way forward for people who work hard and contribute, and protects due process and human rights at the border.

I think immigration rules should be kind and fair, so families can stay together and kids can feel safe and loved, just like me with my mom. People who come here and work hard, follow the rules, and help others should get a chance to be citizens someday. I believe God wants us to share and welcome people, not be mean or leave them out.

I think immigration policy should be fair and humane, giving people who follow the rules and work hard a real chance to become citizens, especially if they’ve built their lives here. Families shouldn’t be torn apart, and kids who grew up in the U.S. should have a clear, affordable path to citizenship. At the same time, the process should be organized and consistent, so it respects both the law and the basic dignity of everyone involved.

As a retired teacher and the daughter of Irish immigrants, I believe our immigration policy should balance compassion with clear, fair rules and a workable path to citizenship. People who work hard, follow the law, and contribute to their communities—often in our schools, hospitals, and farms—deserve a realistic, timely way to become full members of our society. We should protect borders and security, but never lose sight of our moral responsibility to welcome those seeking safety and opportunity, especially families and refugees. In a country built by immigrants, our laws should reflect both our values and our history, not fear or prejudice.

Immigration policy should prioritize national security, the rule of law, and economic needs, with strict enforcement at the border and in the interior. I support a clear, orderly legal immigration process that favors applicants who respect our laws, contribute to our economy, and assimilate into American culture. Any path to citizenship for those already here illegally should be conditional, earned over time through background checks, steady work, tax payment, and learning English, without rewarding those who break the law with an easier route than people who followed the rules.

I believe immigration policy should balance compassion with common sense, welcoming those who are willing to work hard, follow the law, and contribute positively to our communities. There ought to be a clear, orderly path to citizenship that doesn’t drag on for years, with reasonable requirements like learning English and understanding our history and institutions. We should secure our borders and enforce the rules fairly, but we must also remember that many of our own families came here seeking opportunity and safety.

I think immigration rules should be fair and kind, because my church teaches that we should welcome and help people in need. I believe people who come here, follow the laws, work hard, and want to be good neighbors should have a clear and not-too-complicated way to become citizens.

As a Filipino immigrant who became a U.S. citizen through naturalization, I believe immigration policy should be humane, fair, and efficient, honoring both the rule of law and the dignity of people who want to contribute to this country. A strong path to citizenship should reward hard work, tax compliance, and community involvement, while providing clear, achievable steps instead of years of uncertainty. We also need policies that keep families together and recognize that immigrants strengthen our economy and culture, not just as workers but as neighbors, voters, and future leaders.

I think immigration policy should be fair and humane, because families like mine came here to be safe, work hard, and have better opportunities. There should be a clear and reasonable path to citizenship for people who follow the laws, learn the language, and contribute to their communities, so kids like me don’t have to worry about being separated from our parents.

I believe immigration policy should put the safety, economic stability, and cultural cohesion of American citizens first, while still allowing a fair and orderly legal process for those who want to contribute and follow our laws. We need secure borders, strict enforcement against illegal entry and overstays, and a merit-based system that prioritizes workers with skills we actually need. A path to citizenship should be earned over time through legal entry, steady work, learning English, paying taxes, and respecting our values and institutions. For those already here illegally, any discussion of status should come only after the border is secured and must not reward breaking the law with an easy or automatic path to citizenship.

As a naturalized citizen who came here from Myanmar and has built a life serving patients as a physician, I believe immigration policy should be both compassionate and orderly, recognizing the dignity and potential of each person while maintaining clear, consistently enforced rules. The path to citizenship should be rigorous but fair, emphasizing language proficiency, civic education, and economic contribution, and it ought to be accessible to those who work hard, follow the law, and demonstrate a real commitment to the common good.

As a Catholic, a mom, and someone who believes in giving folks a fair shot, I think our immigration policy should balance compassion with common sense and security. We need a clear, humane path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants who work hard, follow the rules, and are raising families here, along with strong protections for DREAMers. At the same time, we should invest in an efficient, orderly legal immigration system that matches our economic needs—especially in industries like mine—while treating every person with dignity and respect.

I think immigration policy should be fair and humane, especially to families and kids who just want safety, education, and a chance at a better life like my family did. There should be clear rules and a reasonable path to citizenship for people who follow the laws, work hard, and contribute to their communities, instead of treating them like they don’t belong. As a Christian, I also feel we should show compassion to strangers and not forget that many of us, or our parents, were once new in a different country too.

As an immigrant who worked hard to become a naturalized citizen, I believe immigration policy should be humane, efficient, and rooted in the idea that people who contribute, follow the law, and build a life here deserve a clear, fair path to citizenship. We should prioritize family unity, worker protections, and due process, while rejecting policies driven by fear or prejudice. A modern democracy like ours benefits from the energy and perspective of newcomers, and our laws should reflect that by making integration, not exclusion, the goal.

As someone who works hard in a busy kitchen and just wants to build a good life for my family, I think immigration policy should balance strong, secure borders with a fair, practical path to citizenship for people who follow the rules and contribute. The process should be clear, not dragged out for years, and should reward those who work, pay taxes, and respect our laws and values. America’s always been about opportunity, but it should be opportunity with responsibility—not open doors with no standards, and not closed doors to people who want to earn their place.

As someone who believes in law, order, and taking care of our families, I think immigration policy should be strict but fair, with secure borders and a clear, enforceable process for coming here legally. We should prioritize people who respect our laws, want to work hard, and share our basic values, while providing a structured, accountable path to citizenship for those who follow the rules. At the same time, we ought to show compassion in how we treat families and children, but without rewarding illegal behavior or creating chaos at the border.

I think immigration policy should be fair and humane, treating people with dignity while still keeping the country safe. There should be a clear, realistic path to citizenship for people who follow the laws, work hard, and want to contribute, especially families and kids who’ve basically grown up here. We also need to consider the impact on the environment and make sure our policies support sustainable communities, not just short-term economic gains.

As a conservative and a proud American born and raised in Florida, I believe immigration policy should put our nation’s security, economic stability, and rule of law first, while still recognizing the dignity and humanity of those who want to come here legally. We should have a clear, enforced border and a streamlined legal process that prioritizes people who contribute to our economy, respect our laws, and share a commitment to our civic values. A path to citizenship should be earned through legal entry, steady work, paying taxes, learning English, and demonstrating good character. That way, we honor both our national sovereignty and the idea of America as a place where people can build a better life if they’re willing to play by the rules.

As someone who believes in the power of music to bring people together, I think our immigration policy and path to citizenship should be fair, humane, and inclusive, giving people who work hard and follow the rules a real shot at belonging here. We should protect borders and uphold the law, but we also need a system that keeps families together, respects human dignity, and recognizes the contributions immigrants make to our culture and economy—just like how different sounds come together to make a stronger track.

As a Vietnamese immigrant who naturalized here, I believe immigration policy should be rooted in fairness, humanity, and respect for the contributions immigrants make to this country. The path to citizenship should be clear, affordable, and timely, with special consideration for families, refugees, and long-term residents who already live, work, and pay taxes here. We should prioritize due process and protect human rights at the border, while also investing in language, job training, and civic education so newcomers can fully participate in and strengthen our communities.

I believe immigration policy should put the safety, economic stability, and cultural cohesion of American citizens first, while still respecting our tradition as a nation of opportunity. We should have secure borders, strictly enforce existing laws, and prioritize legal immigration that brings in people who are willing to work hard, follow the rules, and contribute to our communities. A path to citizenship should be clear, orderly, and earned—requiring English proficiency, background checks, steady employment, and genuine commitment to American values.

As someone who spent decades teaching literature and believes deeply in the stories and talents people bring with them, I think immigration policy should be guided by fairness, compassion, and a recognition of our country’s immigrant roots. We need clear, humane pathways to citizenship that prioritize family unity, respect human rights, and give hardworking people a realistic chance to come out of the shadows. At the same time, the system should be orderly and well-managed, with reasonable security measures that don’t devolve into cruelty or discrimination.

As a naturalized citizen and a nurse who sees every day how immigrants contribute to our healthcare system and communities, I believe immigration policy should be guided by fairness, compassion, and respect for human dignity. We need a clear, realistic, and humane path to citizenship that keeps families together, protects workers from exploitation, and recognizes the vital role immigrants play in our economy and in caring for our most vulnerable. At the same time, we should maintain reasonable security and background checks, applied consistently and without discrimination, so that our system is both orderly and just.

As a Catholic and a conservative, I believe our immigration policy should balance compassion with the rule of law, prioritizing border security and clear, consistently enforced regulations. We should welcome those who come legally, are willing to work hard, respect our laws, and embrace American values, while ensuring that public safety and economic stability for current citizens remain the first responsibility of government. A path to citizenship should be structured, earned, and based on demonstrated commitment to this country—learning English, paying taxes, and contributing positively to the community.

I think immigration rules should be fair and kind, because everyone is made in God’s image and deserves a chance to be safe and build a better life. People who follow the laws, work hard, and really want to be part of our country’s community should have a clear and not-too-confusing way to become citizens.

I think immigration rules should be fair and kind, because my family’s story and a lot of people’s stories start with moving to a new place for a better life. There should be a clear and simple way for families who work hard, follow the law, and want to be part of the community to become citizens so they don’t have to live in fear. Immigration policy should keep people safe, but also remember that kids like me just want our parents and relatives to be together and have chances to learn and grow.

As a software developer who’s spent a career benefiting from talent and ideas from all over the world, I think our immigration policy should be rooted in fairness, humanity, and economic reality. We should have a clear, efficient, and enforceable legal system that offers a realistic path to citizenship for long-term, law-abiding residents, including Dreamers and essential workers, while upholding due process and basic human rights at the border. I’d like to see us prioritize family unity and skills that strengthen our economy, but also recognize that people are more than just “human capital” and deserve to be treated with dignity.

As someone who moved from Spain and isn’t a U.S. citizen, I think immigration policy should be humane, efficient, and fair, recognizing that migrants are people with dreams, families, and talents—not just numbers on a form. There should be a clear, realistic path to citizenship for people who work, study, or build a life in the country, without trapping them in years of uncertainty or fear. I also believe immigration rules should respect human rights and family unity, instead of using borders as a way to divide and dehumanize. For me, a just system is one that balances security with compassion and sees diversity as a strength, not a threat.

As someone who grew up in Texas and loves this country’s promise, I believe our immigration policy should balance compassion with clear, consistent rules. We ought to provide a fair, affordable, and timely path to citizenship for people who work hard, follow the law, and contribute to our communities, including schools and local services like the one I volunteer at. At the same time, we should ensure proper background checks and reasonable border security so the system remains orderly and worthy of the nation we strive to be.

I think immigration rules should be fair and kind, letting people who work hard, follow the law, and want to be good neighbors have a real chance to become citizens. My parents always say everyone is made in God’s image, so we should treat families who come here with respect, but still have good security so people follow the rules. I like the idea of a clear path where immigrants can learn English, pay taxes, and help their communities, and then earn citizenship over time.

As a child care center administrator and a mom, I think immigration policy should be guided by fairness, compassion, and a recognition of how much children and families are affected by our laws. We should create a clear, achievable path to citizenship for people who work, pay taxes, and contribute to their communities, especially those raising children here or who came as children themselves. Family unity and the best interests of children should be central, and our system should protect human rights while still maintaining reasonable, transparent security checks.

I think immigration rules should make sure people are safe and kind, like letting families stay together and helping kids go to school and be healthy. If people want to live here and follow the rules, work hard, and be good neighbors, they should have a fair and not-too-scary way to become citizens.

I believe our immigration policy should balance compassion with practicality, offering a clear, fair, and attainable path to citizenship for people who work hard, follow the law, and contribute to our communities. As someone who comes from a Polish American background and spent my career in education, I’ve seen how immigrants enrich our culture and economy, and I think we should prioritize family unity, human rights, and due process over fear-based politics.

I think our immigration policy should be humane and fair, with a clear, realistic path to citizenship for people who work hard, follow the rules, and contribute to our communities. Growing up here and watching this country change, I’ve seen how immigrants often take on tough jobs and enrich our culture, and they deserve a chance to belong fully. We should secure the border sensibly, but not at the expense of treating people with dignity or breaking up families.

As a Christian, a progressive, and someone who works in higher education, I believe immigration policy and the path to citizenship should be guided by human dignity, family unity, and economic fairness. We should create a clear, affordable, and timely path to citizenship for undocumented people who contribute to our communities, especially those who’ve lived here for years and whose children know no other home. Security and rule of law matter, but they shouldn’t be used as excuses for cruelty, racial bias, or separating families. A just system recognizes that our country has always been strengthened by immigrants and should reflect both compassion and practical economic needs.

Immigration policy should put the interests and security of American workers first, with strong borders and strict enforcement so people can’t just skip the line. I support legal immigration for those who follow the rules, contribute to the economy, and respect our laws and culture, but the path to citizenship should be earned through paying taxes, learning English, and showing long-term commitment to this country.

Immigration policy should be guided by human dignity, fairness, and a clear, realistic path to citizenship that doesn’t criminalize people for seeking safety or opportunity. As someone who works with families in need and believes deeply in social justice and Jewish values of welcoming the stranger, I think we should prioritize family unity, protection for refugees, and regularization for longtime residents who contribute to our communities.

As a Protestant, progressive, Hispanic woman raising kids and teaching in early childhood education, I believe immigration policy should reflect both compassion and common sense. We need a fair, accessible path to citizenship that keeps families together, protects children, and recognizes the economic and cultural contributions immigrants make in our communities and classrooms. At the same time, we should have clear, humane laws and procedures that ensure security without criminalizing people who are simply seeking a better life.

Immigration policy should be based on the rule of law, secure borders, and a fair but firm process that doesn’t reward cutting in line ahead of those who follow the rules. As a naturalized citizen myself, I believe the path to citizenship should emphasize language proficiency, respect for American values and institutions, steady employment, and a genuine commitment to contributing to the community.

As a public school teacher, I see every day how immigrants and their children enrich our classrooms and communities, so I believe immigration policy should be humane, orderly, and firmly grounded in equal opportunity and respect for human dignity. We should provide a clear, realistic path to citizenship for law‑abiding immigrants who work, pay taxes, and contribute to our society, while maintaining reasonable security and fair enforcement.

As someone who works with young people every day and volunteers in my community, I believe our immigration policy should balance compassion with clear, fair rules. We should provide a realistic, structured path to citizenship for people who work, pay taxes, follow the law, and contribute to our schools, hospitals, and neighborhoods—many already do vital caregiving work like mine. Policy needs to protect due process, keep families together, and prioritize humane treatment at the border, while still maintaining sensible security and enforcement. In a country built by immigrants, we’re at our best when we treat newcomers as future neighbors and citizens, not permanent outsiders.

As someone who grew up in a Latino family and sees every day in my barbershop how hard immigrants work, I believe our immigration policy should be based on dignity, fairness, and opportunity. We need a realistic, humane path to citizenship for people who contribute to our communities, pay taxes, and raise their kids here, instead of treating them like they’re disposable. A strong country doesn’t come from shutting people out, but from helping workers and families put down roots, feel safe, and fully participate in the life of our neighborhoods.

As someone who works hard to balance family, community, and career, I believe immigration policy should be fair, humane, and efficient, recognizing that many immigrants contribute to our economy and communities just like my own coworkers and neighbors do. We should have a clear, realistic path to citizenship that rewards those who follow the rules, pass background checks, pay taxes, and are willing to integrate into our society, rather than trapping people in years of red tape.

As a Catholic and a conservative, I think immigration policy should balance compassion with law and order: we should welcome those who follow the rules, work hard, and share our respect for this country’s values. The path to citizenship should be clear, strict, and fair, prioritizing people who contribute, speak English, and want to fully join American society, while making sure our borders are secure and our own citizens’ safety and jobs come first.

My mamá says that people who come here should be treated with kindness and fairness, because God loves everyone, no matter where they are from. I think families should be able to stay together and have a safe place to live, and if they work hard and follow the rules, they should have a chance to be citizens like me.

I think people who want to live here should be nice, follow the rules, and try to help others, just like we learn to do at school. If families are trying to be safe and have a better life, we should try to help them and let them become part of our country if they work hard and are kind. It’s important that everyone who comes here learns our language and our laws so we can all get along and be fair to each other.

I believe immigration policy should prioritize security, respect for the rule of law, and fairness to those who work hard and follow the legal process. We should secure the border, enforce existing laws, and focus on admitting people who are committed to contributing to our communities and our economy. At the same time, for those who are already here, working, paying taxes, and staying out of trouble, I support a rigorous but achievable path to citizenship that includes background checks, learning English, and demonstrating a real commitment to American values.

As someone who came here from Japan, serves on active duty, and is raising kids in this country, I believe immigration policy and the path to citizenship should first protect national security, uphold the rule of law, and prioritize those who are willing to contribute and assimilate. I support a clear, tough but fair process that rewards documented, orderly immigration, expects newcomers to learn English and respect American values, and offers a transparent path to citizenship for those who work hard, follow the rules, and commit to this nation.

As the grandson of Swedish immigrants and a data-minded liberal, I think immigration policy and the path to citizenship should be guided by both moral responsibility and empirical evidence. We should prioritize humane treatment, family unity, and a clear, attainable route to citizenship, while using rigorous data to shape admission criteria that meet labor needs, uphold security, and maximize long‑term social and economic benefits.

As a first-generation Russian American and a Democrat, I think our immigration policy should be rooted in fairness, compassion, and practicality—welcoming people who want to work hard, contribute, and be part of our communities, just like my family did. The path to citizenship should be clear and attainable, especially for long-term residents, Dreamers, and people doing essential work, as long as they follow the law and pay taxes. I also believe we need strong but humane border security, focusing on real threats instead of treating ordinary families like criminals.

As a Catholic and a conservative, I believe immigration policy should balance compassion with respect for the rule of law and national security.
